3462371.subject: Inquisition Pope and Beheading a Royal Couple
3462371.author: berge54

posts.content: Friend and I were playing, and he had the conditions for a  Imperial Victory. It looked like the only way I could stop him was to behead one of his Kings. I had Inquisition Pope in my tableau and a Catholic Bishop on the Queen of his Royal Couple. The ability of Inquisition Pope limits me to beheading cards with either a Cath. or Ref. Bishop on them. I know in most cases, other than ops, you treat the couple as one, but in the case of beheading with Inquisition pope, can I behead the King even though the Bishop is technically sitting on the Queen?? The rules clearly allow for beheading the king in the couple individually, but I'm wondering how Inquisitions's ability specifically interacts with the royal couple. Thanks!!

No - with a Behead Op, only the Queen would be discarded, not the King. See the Glossary entry for "Queen": "If the Queen is beheaded the King is unaffected. The Queen is Killed if the King is beheaded or a REGIME CHANGE occurs." So your further statement about individually allowing beheading of a coupled King is incorrect.

I really kind of wish it were otherwise - since bishops silence both the King and Queen, it would be a lot easier to remember the rules if beheading worked the same way.

3459937.subject: Trade Shift - can the same disk be moved multiple times?
3459937.author: gomatt

posts.content:
Up until present, I have been allowing multiple cards to move trade fair disks of the same color (e.g., the West white disk) due to the one shot abilities on the cards. I recently watched a rules video where it was mentioned that a trade fair can only be moved once and then the remaining one shots for the trade shift are to be ignored. In other words, a trade shift is a one change per game per color.

The rules do not specify this, though the living rules do mention "This reroutes the Trade Route for any future trade fair actions taken of that color."

Can a trade shift be performed multiple times on either colored disk?

Yes, you can perform multiple trade shifts with the same disc. Aside from the fact that the rules don't explicitly prohibit it (and there would be no reason to assume that such a prohibition exists otherwise), the wording of the individual trade shifts clearly implies that it's allowed. For instance, H1c (Novgorod Trade Shift) says:

If Novgorod is covered by a black ‚Äúbusted‚Äù disk, this trade shift moves it from Novgorod to cover the uncovered black Emporium (either Timbuktu or Tana).


Timbuktu would not be the uncovered black Emporium unless a previous Trade Shift had already occurred.
But remember it is not possible retrurn trade discs to starting position in Byzantium as there are no such cards.

"d. Arsenal/Dalmatians. If your Concessions cannot be Killed by Pirates due to an Ability, a Pirate placed on your Concession coexists with it, but cannot participate in trade fairs. However, you are still not allowed to place a new Concession into a Border containing a Pirate."

serewa wrote:

Will it replace the repressed one, but will die from the Pirate?

I don't have time to do a full rules dive right now on this but my quick interpretation would be that the situation you describe is not possible. Concessions cannot be placed where a Pirate is nor can they be targeted for repression by Agent placement or Regime Change. My rationale:

1. No player (including the one with the Arsenal/Dalmations ability) can place a concession where a Pirate is per

Living rules wrote:

E2.2.d: "You cannot place a Pawn into a Border occupied by a Pirate"
Glossary, Regime Change, a: "Place this Concession in one of the Borders of the Empire (without Pirates)."
Glossary, Pirate, d: "However, you are still not allowed to place a new Concession into a Border containing a Pirate."


2. You cannot Repress a Concession coexisting with a pirate using Agent placement or Regime change because the repression is dependent on placing the Concession (which can't be targeted) per

Living rules wrote:

E2.2.d: "Place one Pawn of your color into a Border of your choice of the Empire specified...You cannot place a Pawn into a Border occupied by a Pirate."
Glossary, Regime Change, a: "If the Border chosen is already occupied with a Pawn, you must pay 1 Florin to Repress it." But the preceding sentence (quoted above) prevents the choice of a border with a Pirate "Place this Concession in one of the Borders of the Empire (without Pirates)."

3345385.subject: Solo Rules - placing concession/pirates by bot
3345385.author: siwy9

posts.content:
How should I understand phrase: Choose ‚Äúupstream‚Äù Borders in Trade Routes for solo rules, when bot is placing concession/pirates? Since Eastern and Western Trade Routes go into opposing directions, placing pawn upstream of one route means placing it downstream of second at the same time.
Thank you in advance

The trade routes don't run in opposite directions unless at least one trade shift has occurred. If that does happen, you can choose the location that is nearest to the emporium for its trade route, or just choose whichever one seems likely to help the bot more.

As you work through the solo mode, you're going to find lots of little cases like this here and there, where it seems like the bot's exact play is not well-defined. This was probably inescapable given the complexity of the game, given all the ways that its systems can interact. In such cases, just do whatever seems to make the most sense for the bot. Alternatively, maybe don't even bother with the solo mode and play a two-handed game instead. I find that to be both easier and more fun.
Nearest to the emporium? I think "upstream" means from the end (Mamluk or SIR) to the emporium, so the concession should be placed as nearest to the target (Mamluk or SIR) as possible.

LordPrometheus wrote:

Maybe I'm just being dumb, but I can't find anywhere in the rules where it tells you which kingdom a repressed concession goes to. They're adjacent to two kingdoms usually. Is it optional which one they go to?

Concessions reside on the boundaries between empires, but Repress ops belong to specific empires, and that's where repressed pawns go. This is what F5 means by "its corresponding Empire Square": the empire square that corresponds to the location of the card whose op you're executing. If you're repressing a concession as part of a regime change, then it goes onto whichever empire's regime has just changed.

It'll be the kingdom of the card that had the repress op or the kingdom in which the regime change just happened.

If there is a West or East card with the repress op (I don't recall if such a card exists), then effectively you would choose which kingdom it goes to.

The exploit you're looking for is the crown cheese, which is selling a king-crown pair for 6 florins, then spending 1 to campaign the pair back into your tableau so you can do it again later (and prevent anyone else from doing it).

You may already know about this, but here's an explanation for those who don't:

King-crown pairs: Holy Roman with Reichskrone, or Hungary with Theft of the Holy Crown (these are the only queens that gain you +2 florins in sale). When sold the pair goes to the throne, available to the next player to attack the empire.

Campaigning it back to your tableau for 1 florin is the most efficient way to get the pair back. You ideally have 1 knight available and the target empire is completely open.

As long as you put the pair back into your tableau, no one else can do the same move for themselves with those cards. They can, of course, get rid of the crown by taking the empire for themselves, which is due to the subtly different regime change procedures regarding taking an empire from the throne vs from another player.

No, it's correct. What portion of the example do you think is incorrect?
In order to perform a Vote op, you need to have a majority of concessions bordering, which is met in the example.
That requirement being met, you pay 1 florin for each repressed token - in this case 3 florins for the 3 repressed serfs (not shown in the example, but explained in the text of the example - it doesn't matter what color the repressed serfs are, and if there were also repressed ruling class tokens, that would have also increased the price to perform the Vote op).

In my opinion the cleanest option is to allow the ability to become active immediately.

Ok I think the defining factor here is this. If your free ops are silenced at the time you begin them, and you unsilence in the middle of running them, they do not retroactively become free.

If free ops are unsilenced BEFORE you initiate them, they would become free for your turn.

So, as long as the free action is available at the time you initiate them, they are free. But you don't get a "refund" if you unsilence after you initiate.

This is the card that lets you sell it to do a purple op in an opponent‚Äôs Tableau.

2 questions:

1) Of the intended purple op is on a card that is covered by a Bishop, can I still perform that op?


2) if Cryptography itself is silenced by a Bishop, can I Sell it to do the text?

1. No. There's an entry for Cryptography in the Glossary that answers this question explicitly: "The puppeted card retains all its limitations (e.g., [...] can be silenced."

2. No. When a card with a bishop on it is removed from play, the bishop simply follows along with the card (Glossary again, point C under the entry for Bishop). The bishop doesn't leave play before the card leaves play, so the card's ability is never unsilenced.

So if your tableau contains an ability that says your cards are immune to silencing, then I would say that you could use Cryptography to execute an op on an opponent's card that is silenced, because that card wouldn't be silenced if it were in your tableau.

What‚Äôs the meaning of dominant religion?

A religion is dominant if:

1) It has more bishops on all cards than both other religions combined, AND
2) It has more believers in its religion's theocracies than both other religions combined.

Example:
3 Catholic Bishops, 1 Reformist Bishop, 1 Islamic Bishop
The only theocracies are Papal States (Catholic), Portugal (Catholic) and Mamluk (Islam). Papal States has one Catholic knight, Portugal has one catholic knight and Mamluk has one Islamic rook.

Catholicism is the dominant religion as it has 3 > 2 Bishops and more believers in theocracies (2 > 1).

Note that believers in a DIFFERENT religion's theocracy do not count. So if for whatever reason Portugal also had an Islamic Knight/Rook, it would not count since it is not in an Islamic theocracy.

I hope that is clear!

As with so much in Pax Ren, it really depends on how your specific game goes. If action is concentrated in the West at the beginning of the game, then yeah, you're likely to see trade fairs reaching over to that side of the board early. But if there are early regime changes available in the East, then you're going to have a lot of concessions positioned along the early parts of those trade routes and not many market florins building up in the West, and of course the East trade fair doesn't even reach the West unless someone plays a trade shift.

Most players will look for regime changes early, so concessions come onto the board quickly. So even when there is a lot of play in the West, while it might not be hard to get levies in the first few Western empires along the trade route, it can be very difficult to get them in England, France, or especially the HRE.

Joe is right.

To sum up, I'd say: It *can* happen. It *usually* doesn't (like 70% of the time?).

The frequency with which players activate the trade fairs also impacts how far they can reach in some cases. If people are trade fair-ing often, then the pool of florins for each fair will likely tend to be fewer (since it's whatever has built up since the last fair), and the fair is more likely to conclude before it reaches the end of the route. This can be a legit strategy for players whose concessions lie earlier in the route to trigger the fair sometimes, even if their $$ gain alone maybe wouldn't feel like enough reason to take that action. The Florin economy can be very tight, so maintaining an influx of one or two for yourself, while keeping opponents from getting much/any can make a difference.

If your play group determines that you're playing by the rules, and that trade routes just tend to play out in full a lot of the time, you (or anyone) can use that knowledge to mess with them by prioritizing pirate play, cards with either west/east tax ops, trade shifts, etc, more than maybe they have been prioritized so far. 3198202.subject: Replacing a Cosair with a concession.
3198202.author: Nick Morgan

posts.content: The situation was this, following a successful peasant revolt can I replace a corsair on the border with the concession that comes with a successful regime change. The corsair was on the winning side. Thx.

If the pirate was killed during the battle, then you can place your concession into the border formerly occupied by that pirate.

If the pirate survives the battle, then no, you cannot replace it with a concession. See point (a) under REGIME CHANGE in the Glossary: "If you cause a Regime Change, you always have the option to add one Pawn as a CONCESSION. Place this Concession in one of the Borders of the Empire (without Pirates)." (Emphasis added.) This remains true even if you have a card ability that says your concessions can't be killed by pirates; see point (d) under PIRATE in the Glossary: "If your Concessions cannot be Killed by Pirates due to an Ability, a Pirate placed on your Concession coexists with it, but cannot participate in trade fairs. However, you are still not allowed to place a new Concession into a Border containing a Pirate."

This is covered under Regine Change, in the glossary:
Place this Concession in one of the Borders of the Empire (without Pirates). If the Border chosen is already occupied by a Pawn, you must pay 1 Florin to Repress it.
So you could repress a pawn already there, but not a pirate/corsair.
The fact that your own sponsored Corsairs are hard to get rid of once you no longer need them is somewhat historically accurate üòÑ

The only pieces that ever move from one empire to another on the board are pirates. Knights and rooks stay in their original cities, and concessions stay on their original borders, until they're repressed or killed.

After a successful religious war, the empire in which it was fought will contain ruling class pieces that are (a) believers that were already in the empire prior to the war and were not killed in the battle, (b) agents that were not killed in the battle, and/or (c) any repressed ruling class pieces that you choose to emancipate.

"Concurrently" and "sequentially" have opposite meanings (simultaneously vs. one after the other).

I think your interpretation is correct. See the order of battle section in the Battle glossary entry for what I think is the answer here.

Regime change happens during battle resolution assuming the attackers were victorious. A bishop is placed after the battle, which is after regime change would occur. In second rules quote below you see that regime change is the final part of battle.

The order of operations in the rulebook is intentionally written in sequential order. It describes a battle, regime change if applicable, and then bishop placing:

E2.1a
Battle.
If the One-shot is a Civil or Religious War, the Agent is a Rook, Knight, Pawn, or Pirate that can function as an attacker(s) in a Battle per Part J (conspiracies and peasant revolts) or Part K (crusades, reformations, and jihads). If some survive, they are Victorious and cause a REGIME CHANGE. Bishop Agents do not participate in the Battle but must be placed after the Battle per E2.2a below.


And then under the entry for Battle in the Glossary:

b.
Order Of Battle.
(1) Determine attackers and defenders. All eligible Tokens must fight.
(2) Eliminate attackers & defenders in the exchange. The Battle is victorious if any attackers survive.
(3) Place surviving Agents into the empty Cities,
repressing for free once the Empire is Saturated.
(4) If REGIME CHANGE, optional Emancipation if any empty spaces, plus optional Concession for free either at an empty Border or (for a cost of 1 Florin) repressing a previous Concession.

c.
Agents.
These are attackers, except for Bishops which never fight in a Battle.


It matters a great deal because a bishop can pacify a newly repressed token, and can be placed e.g. on a flipped empire square without fear of it being discarded, as it would were it placed before regime change.

Thankyou Alex, that clarifies it.

Missed the bit in the glossary under Battle at b. (4) that during a Battle Regime Change is part of the order of battle. Had wrongly assumed a Battle ended after determination of whether it was Victorious and should have followed the 4 stages of the order of battle. In effect determining a victor is only the 2nd stage in a 4 stage Battle process.

Will apply that rule correctly from now on.

1. No, it goes into your West tableau. Presumably you're confused by this text from the "easily missed" callout:

The color of the Ops banner (black = East, white = West) indicates which trade deck it belongs in and which side of your Player Board to play the Tableau card or Empire Square. This does not confer special location rules to the card.

This isn't saying that an empire square goes into the side of your tableau indicated by the color of the banner on the tableau card with which you caused the regime change; it's saying that an empire square goes into the side of your tableau indicated by the color of the banner on the empire square itself. The HRE is a Western empire, so it goes to the West. The only way you can have an empire square in your tableau on the opposite side as its location is if a Western empire is a vassal of an Eastern suzerain or vice versa.

2. Inquisitor ops don't have locations. Per F1, an Inquisitor op can move any bishop of the appropriate religion, and the legal destinations for that piece depend on the location of the card on which the bishop currently resides, not the location of the card that has the op. So yes, if the bishop resides on an HRE card, then Inquisitor can move it to any other HRE card regardless of which side of players' tableaus contain those two cards.

posts.content:
Hey!
We played our first game of Pax Renaissance and we think we got most of the rules right after consulting a lot of rules videos, reading the glossary and searching the FAQ. However, I think we might have done something wrong concerning running our East/West ops and, well, this might have changed a big part of the game play.
When running east or west ops, what happens if one your cards does not alter the game state? Can you run that side of yours ops? We ruled that we couldn't but now I worry we might have understood the rules wrong. We thought that this was "part" of building a successful tableau to make sure that your cards did not become unplayable in the process.
In relation to this, if indeed you can't run ops when one of the cards does not alter game state, can you still run your ops and use the inquisitor / behead actions to remove problematic cards from the "ops queue"?
Thank you for your help.

I'm not quite sure I understand the question - running East/West ops is always an allowable action, but I don't see why you would want to do so if it would have no impact. If "one" card's ops would not alter the game state, it doesn't prevent you from using the ops on the other cards on that side of your tableau.
As far as inquisitor / behead ops, they can be used anytime you "run ops" on the side of the tableau where they are located.

And furthermore, just to make sure, there's no required order in which the tableau ops must be performed. For example, if you use an action to run East ops, you can choose the ops in your East tableau in any order that you want - the only limitation being that only one op can be performed on each card. If you use a campaign op on a king card, then later vote that king card into a republic, you can't use another op on that republic, since that 'card' has already been used during that "run ops" action.

I hope that helps!

It sounds like the OP might have been under the impression that you have to use all of your cards when you run Ops, which is not the case. See E4: "If you choose to activate the East Ops as an action, you may perform one Op in each of the cards in your East Tableau. You must perform at least one Op in total if you take this action, and the Op must have a valid target. This is the same in the West." (Emphasis added.) So when you run Ops, you have to use at least one Op in a way that changes the game state, but you are by no means required to use every card. In fact I think the only reason the rules even require you to use one is to prevent the game from reaching a stalemate. (For instance, suppose that there are exactly two cards left in the decks, and you know that one of them is a comet, and neither player wants to be the one to reveal it.)

Hey everyone!

Just had a few quick rules questions around a few edge case interactions:

1. Is selling a Queen + King as a pair a single action that grants you 4 coins? In the same vein, is selling a King + their Crown worth 6 coins in a single action? (My assumption is yes).

2. If you flip an Empire from a Vote, are you then able to immediately use that Empire's ops in the same "Tableau Ops" Action? (my assumption is yes).

3. Let's say that the Holy Roman Empire has 3 Concessions adjacent to it (each belonging to a different player) and there are 3 repressed Concessions (each belonging to a different player). Do I:

a) Choose all the units that will be emancipated first, then choose the order in which they will be placed back into play?
b) Choose a unit to emancipate, have it be placed, and then decide if I want to emancipate more?

In either case, who pays for each repression, and is it mandatory that a player whose pawn was emancipated must pay to repress another if there is no room? That is, can they choose to remain repressed instead?

4. If you run out of Pawns, can you take Pawns from in play to place new Concessions? (My assumption is no).

5. Is it the case that an Empire could flip hands many times if it has no units in it? For example, if I campaign against an empty Empire, is there anything to stop another player from doing the same? (My assumption is there is nothing to prevent this).

6. When campaigning, is it mandatory to send all potential attackers along with the Campaign? For example, if I have 3 Knights in an Empire I control, and I really only need 1 to succeed (or, alternatively, I want to attack but can't afford to send all three, or want to only attack with one), am I able to? (My assumption is that you must send all attackers or none).

7. Can I sell an Empire Square and then immediately take it back in the following action through Jihad, Campaign, etc? (My assumption is yes).

Thanks in advance!

1. Is selling a Queen + King as a pair a single action that grants you 4 coins? In the same vein, is selling a King + their Crown worth 6 coins in a single action? (My assumption is yes).
Yes. E3a specifically says: "A coronated pair (I1) must be sold as a set for 4 Florins total. This is one action."

2. If you flip an Empire from a Vote, are you then able to immediately use that Empire's ops in the same "Tableau Ops" Action? (my assumption is yes).
Yes. The rulebook is explicit about this too, in E4e: " If Victorious, a Strawman vote (F6) against your own King creates a Republic (and vice versa). You may use an Op listed on the new Republic (as long as the card hasn‚Äôt already been used for an Op)."

3. Let's say that the Holy Roman Empire has 3 Concessions adjacent to it (each belonging to a different player) and there are 3 repressed Concessions (each belonging to a different player). [...] In either case, who pays for each repression, and is it mandatory that a player whose pawn was emancipated must pay to repress another if there is no room? That is, can they choose to remain repressed instead?
There is no functional difference between (a) and (b). If you cause a regime change in the HRE while it already has three Concessions bordering it, and it also contains three Serfs, then you cannot emancipate any of the Serfs, because there is no room for them. See point b under REGIME CHANGE in the Glossary: "If you cause a Regime Change in an Empire that has Repressed Tokens, even if they did not fight in a Battle, you may move any or all of the Repressed Tokens from the Empire Square onto its Map Location (into either empty Cities for Rooks or Knights, or into its empty Borders for Concessions)." Also, you can find an example demonstrating this exact scenario labeled Vote Op Example on page 23 of the rulebook.

On the other hand, you can repress existing Concessions with any Pawn Agents who survive the battle (E2d), and/or with the new Concession you gain as part of the regime change (REGIME CHANGE in the Glossary, point a). The cost for those actions is always paid by the player who initiated the regime change. Your questions about who chooses and in what order almost sound like you may be thinking of some of the details of how the Tax Op works (F4) and confusing them with repression.

4. If you run out of Pawns, can you take Pawns from in play to place new Concessions? (My assumption is no).
Yes. See TOKEN MANAGEMENT in the Glossary: "If during card play or adding a Levy a Token should be placed but none remains, remove the necessary Tokens from any Repressed Tokens, or (if this is not possible) from any position."

5. Is it the case that an Empire could flip hands many times if it has no units in it? For example, if I campaign against an empty Empire, is there anything to stop another player from doing the same? (My assumption is there is nothing to prevent this).
You're right: there's nothing to prevent this. It is not only possible but extremely common!

6. When campaigning, is it mandatory to send all potential attackers along with the Campaign? For example, if I have 3 Knights in an Empire I control, and I really only need 1 to succeed (or, alternatively, I want to attack but can't afford to send all three, or want to only attack with one), am I able to? (My assumption is that you must send all attackers or none).
You must use them all. See F9c: "Pay to China 1 Florin for each attacker. To make a campaign, all Knights must attack and all must be paid for."

7. Can I sell an Empire Square and then immediately take it back in the following action through Jihad, Campaign, etc? (My assumption is yes).
Yep, there's no rule against this.

Two questions:

1.) Regardless of whether I do the one-shot or not, I want to play the Bishop Agent. Are the four placement options in the below scenario correct?

if the card that is being played that awards a Bishop Agent and contains a Location that says West, the Bishop Agent can go onto any one of the following Locations:

- Any card that has a Location containing one of the six Western areas in another player‚Äôs tableau.
- My own tableau, on any card that matches one of the six Western Areas.
- My own tableau, on the recently played card that awarded the Bishop Agent.
- A Throne containing it‚Äôs King that is associated with one of the six Western Areas.

2.) if the card that is being played awards a Bishop Agent and contains a Location that says England, the Bishop Agent can go onto any one of the following Locations:
(which of the three series below is correct?)

(Reciprocity with above) - check Inquisitor Ops action on page 19 of rule book that seems to allow for this reciprocity
- Any card that contains the word England or West on another player‚Äôs tableau.
- My own tableau, on any card that matches England or West.
- My own tableau, on the recently played card that awarded the Bishop Agent.
- A Throne containing it‚Äôs King that is associated with England.

OR

(Literal)
- Any card that contains the word England only, on another player‚Äôs tableau.
- My own tableau, on any card that matches England only.
- My own tableau, on the recently played card that awarded the Bishop Agent.
- A Throne containing it‚Äôs King that is associated with England.

OR

(Demarcation is just West / East Locations)
- Any cards of the six Western areas on another player‚Äôs tableau.
- My own tableau, on any cards of the six Western areas.
- My own tableau, on the recently played card that awarded the Bishop Agent.
- A Throne containing it‚Äôs King that is associated with the West.

TIA - responses are greatly appreciated.

1) Any card that either says WEST or has any of the Western icons. This includes cards in your tableau (including the just played card), other players' tableau or the thrones.
2) Any card that either says WEST or has any of the England icons. This includes cards in your tableau (including the just played card), other players' tableau or the thrones.

Note that a card in a tableau may be played on the EAST side, but still be a WEST card (due to coronation or being a vassal)

If you play a EAST (black) queen, you put it on the east side of your player board and then trigger her one-shot, which allows you to put a king on her card. If Papal States is a Vassal of Ottoman: Is it supposed to be in the East or West?

Papal States will be on the East side of your tableau (because it's directly underneath the Ottoman Empire, which is in the East). As such, you can use the Ops on the Papal States empire square while you're running East Ops.

However, the Papal States is still a Western empire. This means that, for instance, if you have a card in hand whose location is West, you can still use its one-shot against the Papal States. Conversely, a one-shot on a card whose location is East cannot target the Papal States. The fact that the Papal States empire square happens to reside on the East side of a player's tableau doesn't change the location of that empire.

You can only run each op side (East ops, West ops) once on your turn, regardless of how many actions it takes to run either or both of them. Similarly, you can only run a trade air once on your turn, regardless of how many actions it takes.

Yes, East/West Ops are separate actions, and each can be performed once per turn - so you can run East Ops and West Ops as your 2 actions. There are also several special abilities that allow you to run East or West Ops "for free" - in these cases it doesn't count as one of your 2 actions, but still count as having run those Ops that turn, so you don't get to run them again.

3014292.subject: Question about the item "One-Shot Occurs. No Battle"
3014292.author: Abirdinthesky

posts.content:
I warmly welcome everyone!

In the item "E2. PLAY HARD CARD & PLACE AGENTS, 1. If One-Shot Occurs. b. No Battle." it is indicated that I am obliged to place an agent and there is a link to item E2.2. It says that if all the cities (for Peace Rock & Knight Agents) and all the borders (for Place Pawn Agents) are occupied, I am obliged to repress the agents and lay out my own.

1. My question is: do I understand correctly that since I am obliged to place agents, performing a One-Shot Occurs (b.No Battle) in a location where all cities (or borders) are occupied, I must necessarily oppress tokens and expose my new ones, paying 1 florin to China?

2. If this is correct, then what should I do if I don't have florins? Does this mean that I can't use "One-Shot Occurs.No Battle"?

Thank you all so much for your help!

Interesting question that I have never had happen in my (admittedly) limited number of games.

In this case I think the rules are clear that the answer to 1) is "Yes" since Agent placement is mandatory if a one-shot takes place. The answer to 2) also appears to be "Yes"; if you cannot pay to place the required Agents, then you cannot implement the one-shot.

Make sure to always have some florins on hand!

This should never be an issue. All one-shots except trade shifts and coronations include battles. Coronations never include agents. Trade Shifts include agents (I don't remember if all do) but also always open up a new city by uncovering the busted Emporium. So there will always be at least one open spot when a trade shift happens.
Any other one-shot (religious or civil wars) there will always be a battle.

E2b reads: "If the One-shot is a trade shift, coronation, or apostasy, there is no Battle and its Agent(s) must be deployed, if there is space for it. See E2.2 below for placement details." (Emphasis added.) I interpret this to mean that you must deploy the agents if there are empty spaces for them to occupy but are not required to repress existing tokens to make room for them. If you were required to repress in the case where there were no empty spaces, then the bolded phrase above would have no meaning, because there would always be space.

OK. This whole issue has started to obsess me, so I did a little research to see how prevalent the OP's situation might be.

According to the card database here in the BGG files, there are a total of 48 No-Battle One-Shots: 17 Coronations, 16 Trade Shifts and 15 Apostasies. None of the Coronations places any Agents, so the question is irrelevant for them. 12 of the Apostasies place only Pirates or Bishops, both of which are placed for free and neither of which suppresses any other Agent. So they are out. 6 of the Trade Shifts place only Pirates or 1 x Rook, neither of which will cause an issue (Pirates for the reason noted above and Rooks because of the point Daniel made in an earlier post).

So this leaves 13 potentially problematic cards (3 Apostasies and 10 Trade Shifts)

The apostasies are Santa Hermandad (1 x Knight: The West), Marechaussee (1 x Rook: The West) and Swabian League (2 x Knight: HRE). The first two are only an issue if every single one of the 6 western locations is saturated. Possible, but not likely. On the other hand, I can see Swabian League potentially requiring a player to suppress Agents in HRE.

As for the 10 Trade Shift cards, 9 of them require the placement of a Pawn. The other one (Conquistadors) requires the placement of 2 x Knights, which like Swabian League can potentially be problematic.

So in summary, I think players will likely not face the OP's situation in any given game, but there is definitely a chance of it occurring.

As for the answer to the OP's question, based on the wording of the Pax Renaissance rules dated March 11, 2021 I would stick to my earlier response. Based on the wording, agents must be deployed and if they can't be, then the player cannot implement the One-Shot (this assumes, of course, that the March 11 rules are the latest iteration of the Living Rules).

Probably an issue that someone should bring up with Phil and the gang at Ion Games.

...this seems like a super noob question, but for example Lizard Union asks to place two red Rooks but the map board clearly shows two brown rooks.

schnapes wrote:

...this seems like a super noob question, but for example Lizard Union asks to place two red Rooks but the map board clearly shows two brown rooks.

What am I doing wrong?


When you play a card, you ignore the printed symbol on the board. In practice, you are manipulating the area with new miniatures and composition of pieces.
Remember that this piece can only be placed on the active realm on the card.

If you're placing Agents, the color and type of the Knight/Rook need not match what's printed on the map. For Levy, they do need to match. See the glossary entries for City (page 39) and Levy (page 40).
Printed icons matters only for levies during trade fairs or tax operation.

3056100.author: DaphneHopkins

posts.content:
Playing 4-handed solo. Coeur gained control of the Ottoman Empire through arranging a royal marriage. Then, Marchionni launched the Qizilbash in a jihad against the Ottomans. Now historically, the Qizilbash were Shi'ites, and the Ottomans were Sunnis. In the game, however, there appears to be no functional difference. The only reason Marchionni could even launch the jihad was that there was one Catholic rook in Rhodes. So in game terms, Marchionni's Qizilbash targeted the Catholic rook, but thereby snagged the Ottoman Empire from Coeur through a regime change...if I'm playing correctly. I placed the new Islamic Theocracy card on the map.

Does that all sound kosher? The really weird part is that the Qizilbash actually used the Ottomans' own green pieces against itself, since they were, in game terms, believers.

You have to follow the rules not the theme, so yes this is correct.

If you need a thematic tie in, imagine that the Qizilbash (Alevi) tradition gained a following amongst the Janissaries and this led to Alevis establishing themselves as the predominant sect in the Ottoman Empire.

In fact, it's not that far-fetched. The Bektashi order had a long history of popularity with the Janissary corps - this being one of the reasons for their eventual abolition in the early 1800s - and Hacƒ± Bekta≈ü Veli was revered by both the Qizilbash and Bektashis. Even today you'll find them both making the same pilgrimage to his resting place in central Anatolia.

Interesting! Thank you. It's an interesting feature of the game that the Ottoman Empire is so hard to obtain, because of its strength. But an eastern jihad can easily target it, because it already has so many Islamic pieces in the ruling class. I suppose it simulates the fragility of having a fractious, state-sponsored religion.
The Ottomans are certainly a difficult to obtain but worthwhile prize. If I get them I try to ensure their religious "purity" to make them less susceptible to jihad.

Right,  "cosmopolitan" (in terms of religion) Empires are more susceptible to religious wars. Empires with lots of repression are harder to use votes against, Empires that see lots of trade are harder to topple with civil wars or campaigns, but usually easier to topple with religious wars. Also, Empires that see lots of regime changes tend to see... more regime changes, generally. In other words, regime changes beget more instability, as players fight over them instead of building them up with trade.
What is the significance of a polymath? Where in the rules are they discussed? Where is the symbol listed?
That's not a term that's part of the rules. That's just a label for the flavor text.

3005341.subject: Question about voting on a target in someone else's tableau.
3005341.author: ziggysab

posts.content: If I run a successful vote ops and turn a kingdom into a Republic in somebody else's tableau, does the new Republic go into my tableau or does it flip to Republic in its current tableau? Its a regime change which would have made me think the card moves to my tableau, but then the glossary also says "A Republic can only be gained through a successful self-inflicted attack (vote, civil war, religious war)", which makes me think it stays where it is. So I'm just looking for clarification on how this is supposed to work. Thanks!

Neither of those is correct. The target empire doesn't become a Republic at all; it goes into your tableau (because you're the one who initiated the regime change) on its King side. See the glossary entry for regime change: "Unless it is already in your Tableau, move the Empire Square to your Tableau on its King side, in the furthest East or West position as appropriate." Also see F6c for the rules as they apply to the Vote op specifically: "If the Empire Square is in an opponent‚Äôs Tableau, you gain it as a King. If it is in your Tableau, flip it to its other side (King or Republic)."

This is why, as you noted, the glossary entry for Republic says that you can only gain one through a successful, self-inflicted attack.

Yes, you essentially have three actions every turn, but no, you can't use them in that way. You can only run west ops once per turn, and east ops once per turn. The special abilities that let you run either side of your tableau without expending an action, or both sides as a single action, do not supersede that restriction.

So, on your turn you can run east ops without expending an action. You could then use one of your two actions to run west ops, but you wouldn't get to run your east ops again. Your third action would have to be used for something other than ops.

In essence, once you have either of the two abilities you've cited, adding the second one doesn't give you a whole lot extra. You get some redundancy, in that someone wanting to take away your free ops would have to behead or silence two cards instead of one. And the "free east ops" card is somewhat more flexible than the other one because it doesn't require you to spend an action and thus permits more combinations of actions on your turn. But that's it.

B10. BATTLES
Battles allow you to influence the board state and, when Victorious, enact a Regime Change (B11). To resolve a

The answer to all of the above: yes, no matter the previous status of the empire (vassal, coronated king, republic, etc.) It always moves to the leftmost (for western) or rightmost (if east) position in your tableau after regime change - with 2 exceptions.

Activate Eastern Ops (E4).

1. Placing a concession after a regime change and paying 1 florin to displace an existing concession
2. Using the Repress op to repress a specific type of piece and gaining 1 florin

In brief, you can repress when placing agents, during the placement of a concession as the result of a regime change, using the repress op, using the tax op, or as the result of a trade shift or having more survivors after a battle than there are spaces for in an empire.

I think that the Repress entry in the glossary has a decent summary of the different situations and if payment/gains apply:

REPRESS - This removes a Ruling Class or Concession Token from the Map, which becomes a Repressed Token that is set on the Empire Square, whether in a Throne or a Tableau.
a. Cost. If you repress as a result of Agent placement (E2.2) or a Regime Change, the cost is 1 Florin paid to China.
b. Gain. If you repress as the result of the repress op (F5), you gain 1 Florin from China.
c. Free. If you repress as a result of the tax op (F4) or trade shift (H1), there is no cost or gain. If there are more Victorious survivors after a Battle than Cities or Borders to house them, repress them for no cost.
d. Serfs. The Location of a card used to repress a Concession determines which Empire it enters as a Serf.

Thanks, yes I had forgotten about the Tax op of course. I agree the glossary is helpful. I didn't realize that you could repress any unit when placing agents nor that you had to pay to do so. I also had been playing the trade shift rule wrong - I thought the unit was killed rather than repressed. I understand the Victorious survivors condition as well; basically you choose what goes on the map and what becomes repressed (or remains repressed). The serf concept is oddly specific but very useful for clarifying where pawns go - I have had the question before but intuited the answer correctly.

E2.2b and E2.2d in the rules (placing Agents if no One-shot) state that you get to choose where Rook, Knight, and Pawn Agents are placed. If there are tokens already in the City or Border you choose, then you must pay 1 Florin to Repress each token (exception: you can't place Pawn Agents into a Sea Border occupied by a Pirate). Agent placement in this context is totally independent of whether or not an Empire is Saturated.

Using your last example: Playing a card with 2 Rook Agents and a Location in an Empire with 3 Cities, only one of which is occupied, you could place 1 Rook into an empty City and the other into the occupied City, paying 1 Florin to Repress the Token there. You could alternately place only one of Rooks, choosing the occupied City, and paying 1 Florin to Repress.

The depends on type of the battle.
In civil war (peasant revolt or conspiracy), agents from card are attackers and agents on empire are defenders - it doesn't really matter if the empire is full, as you have to kill all defenders and have some surviving attackers to win. You then place only surviving attackers.
Holy war (reformation, jihad and crusade) is more complicated - agents from card, agents of the same color on target empire and rooks of the same color from neighboring empires are attackers. Agents of different colors on target empire are defenders. In that case agent from cards are "virtual" units until it is time to place them. And if there is no free space on the empire, you can repress the old agents to place new ones.

I place the attackers next to the target empire to visually compare attackers and defenders - but this does not count as "placing" the units. Only surviving attackers are placed into open spots (cities for knights and rooks, borders for pawns, cards for bishops which do not fight).

The answer to your question is option B (if there is indeed a knight in Venice and the attackers vs. defenders is 1 to 1).

Your two options when playing a card are:

Option 1) Do not trigger the one-shot, and you MAY place none, some, or all agents. You MAY repress existing tokens if you want, paying 1 florin for each repressed token.

Option 2) Trigger the one-shot. In this case, the attacking agents are placed next to the target (but not in any slots yet) (you must use all eligible attackers, including all agents) (bishops are not attackers and are placed at the very last step, and can pacify repressed tokens if placed on an empire card), and you resolve the battle immediately with 1:1 casualties. IF you have any surviving attackers, they must go to an open, available space. If there are no open spaces, the surviving attacker(s) is repressed for free. Then, when placing your new pawn during Regime Change, you may pay 1 to repress an existing pawn.

The rules are a bit scattered throughout the rulebook, but look up the the rule for Play Hand Card & Place Agents (E2) on page 14 of the rulebook, Civil Wars (J1, J2) on page 32, Religious Wars (K1, K2) on page 34, and Regime Change in the glossary on page 41. Regarding regime change, I wish the glossary entry included what to do in the case of a Strawman attack, as well as a Strawman Coronation...the rules for those are presumably written elsewhere in the rulebook (but aren't relevant to your specific example anyway).

Ren can be a bit of a beast to learn. Now that you've tried a game out I suggest rereading the rules and the glossary (the glossary is REQUIRED reading for this game since it contains important game rules) to see if more sinks in. It is totally worth the effort!

If a city is unoccupied it can:
Receive levies during a trade fair (placing a token in an unoccupied city)
Allow the Empire it resides in to be targeted by a Tax op (resulting in receiving a levy and placing a token in an unoccupied city)
Accept emancipated tokens after a regime change (placing them in unoccupied cities)

The basic rule in Pax Ren is that each city can hold 1 token (see City glossary entry); Constantinople breaks that rule because it is a single city that holds 3 tokens. For purposes of checking whether it can accept levies or emancipated tokens it is treated like an empty city if it has fewer than 3 tokens.

Edited to clarify the conflicting language I presented in the short answer and longer answers. Shorter short answer is like Kevin responded, in all 3 Vassal examples you've shown the Queen and bishop are retained as the Vassal returning to its throne is not due to it experiencing a regime change.

Very astute questions. I think the confusion arises from the way these rules are split up and/or repeated across multiple glossary entries.

My short answers to your questions are:
1) No, Queens and Bishops are not retained in case #3 (i.e. Regime Changes), regardless of Suzerain/Vassal status
1) Yes, the Queen and Bishop of the Vassal are retained in case #3 since the Vassal did not experience the Regime Change itself and was moved as the result of the Suzerain's Regime Change (see answer to #3 below).
2) Repressed Tokens are never discarded as a result of moving an Empires Square
3) A Vassal returning to its throne is not considered a Regime Change

More detail behind the rationale for each of the short answers above:
Another edit:
1) Empire Squares undergoing a Regime Change are never returned to their throne as the result of a Regime Change. Regime Changes do not result in the discard of empire squares, rather they move empire squares from their throne or another Tableau to your Tableau, or flip an empire square in your Tableau). In the case of Vassals whose Suzerain undergoes a Regime Change, the Vassal returns to its throne, but does not experience a Regime Change itself and so the Queen and bishop are retained.

Subsequently, the language about Regime Change in DISCARD a). isn't applicable (and should be removed). What seems to have happened here is a copying of language from other sections (e.g. the glossary entry for QUEEN) that detail the two instances when Queens are discarded. The way I teach it is that Bishops and Queens 1) follow Empire Squares to and from the throne, except for Queens in the case of beheading, and 2) are discarded in Regime Changes.

2) Per the glossary entry for REPRESSED TOKEN, "If an Empire Square with Repressed Tokens moves, the Repressed Tokens remain on the tile." You have correctly identified the instances when these tokens may be affected though (Civil Wars, emancipation, pacification).

3) Again, returning a Vassal (or any empire square) to its throne is not a Regime Change. While in the case of Vassals this may have been initiated by the Regime Change of a Suzerain, the Vassal itself has not undergone a Regime Change.

If I've misunderstood some of your questions or my responses don't make sense, let me know, happy to discuss more.

Great questions, answers from my understanding of the current rules are as follows (please correct me folks if I'm wrong!):

1. Yes a bishop can be placed on an unclaimed empire square in its throne. Regarding their movement from thrones, remember 2 things: a) per F1c you may not move a bishop on a throne directly to another throne (i.e. they don't move adjacently between thrones like they would tableau cards) and b) per F1, bishops can move to another card that has the same location as the one it currently sits on (in any tableau or throne). This means that a Bishop on a throne could be moved to any tableau card with that empire square's same location using the inquisitor action.

2. Correct, if there is no opponent tableau where your bishop can be placed, you must place the bishop in your own tableau (often the card that causes the bishop placement). However, remember from your question #1 that you can also place bishops on empire squares in their thrones. Assuming you don't have the empire square matching the bishop's location in your tableau, that is another option. Whether you want to place them in your own tableau, the throne, or an opponent's tableau will depend greatly on the board state. Sometimes you really need to protect those bishops for a religious victory (or preventing an opponent's) and the best way is keeping them in your tableau.

3. Yes, republics are part of your tableau and can be silenced by bishops just like kings. Bishops are discarded as part of strawman regime changes (see the glossary entry for Regime Change, section d, "If the Empire Square comes from its THRONE, it comes with its Bishop (if any) and Queen (if any). If the Empire Square comes from an enemy Tableau, or if it is flipped in your own Tableau (see STRAWMAN), Bishops and Queens are Discarded and any Vassals returned to their Thrones." So in your example, the bishop would be discarded.

Land borders don't matter. Sea borders are the ones with a trade route line running through them, and only matter for placing pirates. So there's only 4 non-sea borders on the map: Byzantine-Mamluk, HRE-Hungary, HRE-Papal, and France-Aragon.

So the answer to both your questions are yes, since a trade route arrow crosses these borders.

during a solo play (managing a 1v1 setting) I operated a one shot, if I am not mistaken it was a peasant revolt or a campaign, that ended in repressing a pawn on the border of the kingdom. My question:
1) It is a legal move? can one's pawn be repressed on a kingdom card that is held in one's tableau?
2) How can the pawn be released? I remember that releasing a repressed piece takes 1 florin, but as far as I know it happens in a regime change and not at any turn in which you own your own repressed pawn in your tableau?
3) A more general question: can the Operations (such as Corsair, Tax, Commerce, Campaign, etc. - not the one shot) be operate only in the kingdom/region mentioned on the card or anywhere on the board (as in Pax Pamir's operations of tableau cards)?

Thank you!

1) Yes, but of course if you instigated a regime change then you should have taken the Empire card into your own tableau.
2) You can't emancipate a repressed token at will. It can only happen as a result of a regime change, in which case you can choose to emancipate any or all of the repressed tokens for free. (Of course, the action that caused the regime change might itself have cost florins - e.g. a vote costs one florin per repressed token.)
3) Only on the location of the card. Some cards say "East" or "West" rather than an Empire name, in which case the Op can apply to any Empire in that area. Exceptions: Vote, which can be in any Empire in the East or West depending on the icon on the Op symbol; and Commerce, which takes a coin from either an East card or a West card depending again on the icon on the Op symbol.

2683289.subject: Timing of token repression on one shots

posts.content: I have a question about the steps during a one shots. As an example, say there is a Conspiracy one shot in France, and it has a Rook and a Knight on it. The card being played with the one Shot has one Knight agent on it. Are you supposed to place the agent on the map first? In the rule book, deploy agent is listed as the first thing you do. So is it possible to pay to repress tokens on the map card to the empire square before the battle happens, so that those now repressed ruling class tokens will participate in the conspiracy?
No, you only repress after the Battle.

If the one-shot is a civil or holy war, and you decide to activate it, then the agents capable of fighting in the battle fight in the battle. After a successful battle, even before resolving the regime change, you must place in the Empire any surviving agents and any repressed tokens that fought in the battle, repressing for free any of them for which there is no space.

On the other hand, if you decide not to activate the one-shot (or if it is a one-shot that doesn't initiate a battle) you may decide to put its agents in play right away; if you decide to place an agent in a city or a border occupied by another token, you must repress it at the cost of a florin.

So in your example, when you play the french card, you can:
1) decide to activate the Conspiracy one-shot; in this case the knight agent fights in the battle, killing the rook or the knight in France (assuming there are no other attaking pieces, the conspiracy fails because there is still one defender and no more attackers);
2) decide not to activate the one-shot; in this case you may decide to deploy the agent knight in the last remaining unoccupied french city, or pay 1 florin and place it in the place of an existing piece, which you repress;
3) just play the card, ignoring both agents and the one-shot.

Hope this helps!

I'm pasting below point i. of Battles, in Glossary.

i. Placement. Any surviving Agents or Repressed Tokens used as attackers in a Battle must be placed in the conquered Empire Square (until it is Saturated). Any remaining Repressed Tokens on the defending Empire may be Emancipated (see REGIME CHANGE). Knights and Rooks go into empty Cities (ignoring the city icon), Pirate ships go into empty Sea Borders, and Pawns (including Serfs) go into empty Borders. If there is not enough room in Cities or Borders because of Saturation, the excess are placed on the Empire Square as Repressed Tokens.

p40 of Book I rules wrote:

"The East" Religious, Political & Military Ops. I agree with hazered's ruling's above.

If you read the full text of the glossary entry for "Location" the phrase after what I quoted makes this even more clear: "Thus each time a 'The East' card is used, e.g. for One-shots, Agent placements, or targets of political and military ops (these are purple and dark red in color), the phasing player chooses one of the four Eastern Locations for it."

While you "can" consider a "The East" card to be in any of the specific Eastern Locations for an op (i.e., it is your choice whether it becomes a specific location), you must do so for political and military ops to actually function. This is clarified for taxing specifically in F4b (added in the living rules) which specifies that "The East/The West. These cards are considered to be in all of the Empires of the East or West, so that the taxing player specifies which Location/Empire is being levied."

To summarize: when executing Ops the phasing player will determine the Empire Location of "The East/The West" card, in any Tableau, required for the Op to be executed and the card will temporarily gain Location Specificity of that Empire until the end of that action. The East/West card can thereafter gain a different Location specificity in subsequent Ops actions. Furthermore, a "The East/The West" card cannot be treated, for Ops purposes, as an entire region having simultaneously all internal and external borders of the broader geography defined by East or West. In other words, Ops can only ever be executed as an Empire location, and executing Ops as a broader East/West overall region AND maintaining Empire ambiguity is NOT permitted.

Shorter:
When executing Ops the phasing player will determine the Empire Location of "The East/The West" card, in any Tableau, required for the Op to be executed. The card will temporarily gain Location Specificity of that Empire until the end of that action. Ops, to be executed, require an Empire Location. Executing Ops as a broader East/West overall region AND maintaining Empire ambiguity is NOT permitted.

Yup. General rule:

Empire cards change hands with Regime changes.

- Empire cards that come into to your tableau, come as Kings.
- Empire cards that are currently in your tableau become republics.

- Empire cards that are currently in your tableau become republics.

Throwing in some quotes from the rules to help guide posterity in understanding the answers that have been provided in the thread.

1) Per the glossary entry for Discard, point a, "Return discarded Empires to their Throne along with any Vassals..." The wording is a little bit tricky because it is trying to cover both cases with one sentence to save space but it means that if a Suzerain is discarded, it is returned to its Throne and its Vassals are returned to their Thrones. 2) Per the Campaign Op Example tip on page 25 "Tokens never move out of their Empire as a result of a Battle (even Adjacent Knights used in campaigns or Religious Wars return home after the fight)." Adjacent Knights are neither Agents (pieces listed on cards) nor Repressed Tokens, even though they are attackers.

The glossary entry seems not to have been updated from 1st edition where the ability was "During your "perform west ops" action, you may perform one political op in a foreign tableau." These are good questions. To set the stage for my responses: in the example on page 33, Aragon is in your opponent's tableau and has 1 repressed red knight. Aragon is also a Suzerain with France as its only Vassal.

1. The red knight is repressed in Aragon (not explicitly depicted in the image but mentioned in the example text "the attackers consist of a repressed red knight on the Aragon Empire Square"). It could be legally placed in any empty city in the empire (Valencia, Algiers, or Timbuktu).
2. France is not taken into your tableau, the example states that "France...gets returned to its Throne." This means that since France was a Vassal to Aragon, and Aragon underwent a Regime Change, it can't stay in your opponent's tableau (the suzerainty has been dissolved). As a result, it returns to the Throne space on the board. All of this is contextualized by the fact that since house of Borgia has a location as "The West" you can target any location in the west (in this case Aragon).
3. The House of Borgia card is not placed onto a card in your tableau (it is placed as a card in your tableau though), the example states "you place the Borgia Bishop on any Tableau card in the West." This means that the agent on the House of Borgia card, a Catholic bishop, is placed on any Tableau card in the West (again, because the House of Borgia card has a location of "The West"). If the location on the House of Borgia was Aragon, the bishop would need to be placed on a tableau card (yours or an opponent's) with Aragon as its location.

Do those clarifications make sense? The example is presented in a narrative style that requires some piecing things together which is much easier if you have the rules sorted in your head already.

While I agree that the rules do not explicitly instruct about the timing of agent placement for trade shifts, I think that what Alex responded with is the interpretation that most closely follows the rules that are present for agent placement if a one shot occurs:

1. Agents participate in the one shot if able (I would argue that even for battles, agents aren't "placed" beforehand since there are no requirements for open cities etc., that would normally be associated with placement).
2. Following one shot resolution, agents are placed.

In the case of a trade shift, the agents don't participate in the one shot but must be placed after it is resolved (like what happens with bishops and one shots resulting in battles).

I can only presume that agents aren't placed before resolving a one shot precisely because their placement can be affected by the one shot (e.g., placing a bishop before a one shot battle could result in a regime change and discarding of that same bishop, likewise in your example, the trade shift can open up a new city for agent placement). I think the idea of the levy is that money is drawn off the trade route to fund armies. It is just that any money the players see from that transaction is minor compared to what they take through their concessions.

With regards to the use of the word "China" I believe a big motivation for exploration was trying to find better routes to the East (India and China). And China in particular was hoarding silver at that point.

The coins in Pax Pamir are thematically explained as political capital, i.e. your followers. It's a closed economy because they're not leaving anywhere.

I can't speak for the "why" of Renaissance, but I'm guessing the thematic intent is that paying coins -- repressing people, confiscating taxes, and paying armies to stomp around and destroy things -- aren't creating more wealth and prosperity in Europe, but causing a net loss.

You're not directly sending the money to China, but in a roundabout way it's eventually going in that direction because the demand for eastern trade isn't gonna stop. So the kingdoms are paying to replace what they lost in the destructive wars.

Although I have used a closed economy before, I don‚Äôt like using this in a trading game. Because trading is not zero-sum, both parties profit, values are created. Money is pumped into the European economy.

Things like levies and campaigns drain money out of the system. China is merely a convenient placeholder for this.

I embarrassed myself in the playtest by thinking that levies take money out of the economic system. This was my original Design intent, but it abandoned early in development. A detail I forgot. The game designer has a special disadvantage playing his own game, because all the design possibilities are still swirling in his head. I call this the Banks syndrome, for fellow game designer Bill Banks, who first identified it to me.

The original design goal was that all money in the game would be generated in the oriental trade. Under feudalism, cash was quite rare. The nobles squeezed food from the serfs, not money. The armies were conscriptees. Specialists were uncommon.

Bankers changed all that, and transformed Europe into a cash society dominated by merchants.

To answer these questions about Cryptography, I'd rather get back to the essence of the game, in which we're bankers pulling the strings...
As I see it, when a card joins your tableau, the agent becomes sort of an "employee" of yours, providing you with the ability to run the ops they can. Yet, the game doesn't show up the fee you have to pay your bribed employees (say, whenever you ask them to provide you with a little service, like "beheading"). Reason is: it is so small in comparison to the amount you've needed to deploy them & execute their one-shot schemes, the game doesn't cover it.
By playing the card "Cryptography", you then "employ" a team of cryptographs (located in the Papal States), able to break the secret code other bankers use to transmit their order to the "employees" of their own. Therefore, using cryptography means you send yourself the order to the aforementioned agents, through the code of their real "boss", to execute your own ploys, & the agent himself is deceived & believing it's their true employer that sent them that order...

So, when you use cryptography, you use the ops of a foreign tableau card (being West or East), as if it were in your own tableau!
As such, it is the location of the foreign card that is used for the op, it is silenced by a bishop, it can't behead itself, and if it beheads an empire card, then it must be discarded, but not the Cryptography.

I know, Phil Eklund had written quite the opposite somewhere else, but that's the way we play this card, as it makes more sense thematically!!
